comments.content: If eFuse was used, would it just disable the device, or would it also wipe the drive? Because if it doesn't wipe the drive, eFuse might not be very useful. Somebody could just yank the drive.

A
You can only use an eFuse once, it's a PROM technology. Containerizing the application and storing all data in an encrypted container space won't permanently disable the device and will provide high levels of protection.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Programmable_ROM

discussion.content:
Maybe: B. Use encryption keys for sensitive data stored in an eFuse-backed memory space that is blown during remote wipe?
PII is often intertwined with other data. It would be difficult to separate out the PII and put it in some special encrypted space.
eFuse can remotely disable the device.

To prepare for an upcoming audit, the Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) asks for all 1200 vulnerabilities on production servers to be remediated. The security engineer must determine which vulnerabilities represent real threats that can be exploited so resources can be prioritized to migrate the most dangerous risks. The CISO wants the security engineer to act in the same manner as would an external threat, while using vulnerability scan results to prioritize any actions.
Which of the following approaches is described?

discussion.content: act the same way as an external threat...black box test.

Selected Answer: B
I concur with B. Read team
BTW: I suspect the question means "mitigate" not "migrate."

This question is worded so poorly, and the options don't help at all. Because it doesn't seem to give any key words for black box other than vulnerability scan, I'd have to go with Red Team. I just don't see it really inferring that they know nothing about the network. 

The security engineer himself is doing the test, he's going to know the logical diagram of the network whether he means to or not. I feel like a black box would have someone who doesn't know the network as well. I just have to go with red team here.

answer is b R
Red Teaming is a full-scope, multi-layered attack simulation designed to measure how well a companyâ€™s people and networks, applications and physical security controls can withstand an attack from a real-life adversary.

comments.content:
The question seems to be self contradictory:

It is unlikely that an external threat wouldhave a vulnerability report.

No because it says that he will use the vulnerability scan to assist. Black box is a zero knowledge test. Red teams purpose is to think like an attacker, but have the benefit of inside knowledge. Red team 100%
The question is referring the approach used by the team, not what type of team is using the approach. It's a black box test.

discussion.content:
Maybe B. Red team ? 
A red team acts in the same manner as an external threat. 
Black box means the attacker is given no information about the network. But if the security engineer has a vulnerability scan, that would give the security engineer a great deal of information about the network.

questions.question_text: A security manager recently categorized an information system. During the categorization effort, the manager determined the loss of integrity of a specific information type would impact business significantly. Based on this, the security manager recommends the implementation of several solutions. Which of the following, when combined, would BEST mitigate this risk? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: given answer is correct because they both target integrity

Selected Answer: C
"Backup solution that implements daily snapshots" is correct because RPO (recovery point objective) is "refers to the amount of data that can be lost within a period most relevant to a business, before significant harm occurs, from the point of a critical event to the most preceding backup." -- https://www.acronis.com/en-us/articles/rto-rpo/
